positive_comments: Logistical items: •	Adding the video quality reminder at the top of each video is helpful.  Article 1:  •	I like that the article lists challenges, including what I mentioned above about missing good candidates. If AI cannot overcome these challenges, then what? What is the outcome? What is the solution? The article and the module sort of mentions challenges as a very small part, but doesn’t reveal how to overcome them.
improvement_opportunities: Logistical items: •	The videos in Module 4 cut off the speech at each transition. •	Were these videos created with U.S. employment in mind? I ask because the video re: EE Wellness in Module 4 has examples and encourages AI use in ways that will get a U.S. employer in a lot of trouble. See my notes in that section.  Video 1 •	The video title says, “The ‘new reality’ of Customer Experience (CX)” – is this the correct title?  •	Additional concerns about video content (see attached) Article 1 - concerns regarding content (see attached) Video 2 - concerns regarding content (see attached) Discussion Q2 - •	Recommend changing the question from “Can you think of any drawbacks…” to “What are the drawbacks of…” Assignment 1: • Recommend including the word “current” in the assignment title, so it would say, “Map Your Current Recruitment Processes.” Assignment 2: • Instructions make it seem like this is a collaborative assignment, but that’s not the case if they are completing it and submitting it. Should this be a Discussion Q instead?  Discussion Q3: •	This question has nothing to do with the article. Is that intended?  Capstone Project Description: • Says, “Set specific and quantifiable customer experience objectives…” Is that right? Shouldn’t it be related to AI in HR?
show_stopper_details: Incorrect titles/descriptions. Concerns about content posing legal risks. See attached for details.

positive_comments: Video 4: •	Using AI as a wellness tool is okay, if the employer has NO access to the health (including mental health) information obtained.
improvement_opportunities: Discussion Q1: •	I recommend adding, “why/why not” to the question.  Video 2: •	What does the Accenture example have to do with performance management? It wasn’t made clear. It seemed like it was referring to its use for B2C.  Discussion Q2, Article: •	Is this a verified blog? There are spelling/grammatical errors within.   Assignment 1: •	The instructions say to discuss answers with fellow learners, but this is an assignment. Should it be a Discussion Question instead? Otherwise, where should they discuss their answers? Video 3: •	Has a glitch – it repeats two parts of the video. Video 4: •	The description under this video is Video 3’s description.  •	The IBM Watson example concerns me. •	The Humanyze example for ID Badges is another privacy issue.  Discussion Q3: •	This question should be after Video 3. It is about compensation and has nothing to do with Video 4.  Capstone Project Description: • Says, “Set specific and quantifiable customer experience objectives…” Is that right? Shouldn’t it be related to AI in HR?

positive_comments: A really nice balance of learning interactions, videos, articles, discussions. It was an appropriate amount of time to introduce the course.
improvement_opportunities: Level setting of what AI is and is not would have been good. The first article makes some assumptions that the learner knows some basics and many do not in this space. Articles are a bit dated for an area that is changing so rapidly.  The Role of Artificial Intelligence in Modern HR video (intro 1 of 11) It starts from the perspective that people know what these things are (large language model, IBMs Watson, etc) and many may not.   Article in 2/11 is from 2021 (AnalysticsSteps.com). AI has changed so much and although the article isn’t wrong, an article dated that old may not have as much credibility as it could with something more recent. Article from Business News Daily, Ways AI is Changing HR Departments was a good article and reinforced a lot of key points. The discussion in 4/11 section could be just as effective without needing a second article.   In the videos, the narrator’s alternative pronunciation of words is distracting. I wasn’t sure at first if it was due to an accent but I do not think so. I also was asking my self if the narrator is an AI bot - that would be clever if he is.  Nit-picky of me but that’s a lot of exclamation points in the first paragraph of the linked instructions for Your Canvas Assignments (4 including the title) on how to download and submit assignments. ￼  The text in the 4/11 Discussion prompt has a sentence in there that I’m not sure is worded right. The last sentence, “However, resistance to AI can hinder efficiency, support remote workers, talent acquisition, productivity, and organizational competitiveness’ seems to be making a couple different points that don’t all fall under resistance to AI. Are there verbs missing for talent acquisition, productivity, etc?  Oracle’s AI in Human Resources article is good but also very dated as its from 2018. This article may be better as a part of an earlier section as it sets up what is AI vs Machine Learning vs Digital Assistants. The older article wouldn’t feel as dated if used to set up a bit of foundation around ‘what is AI’.

positive_comments: Great real world examples that call out actual companies by name. The activity of mapping out your org’s recruitment process is great and allows the learner to take a step back and think about the process at their own org which I’m sure many (outside of recruitment) have not done.   The assignment 1 in section 5/12 - the Value Framework is a good assignment that gets folks thinking about their process and where they can apply AI.   I love the real world examples shares from Unilever and Mya, Jacque Reed, etc, showing something from their platform would make it even better.
improvement_opportunities: The introduction of different AI tools into the recruitment process seems to be missing the risks that come with it (HR, Legal, bias, loss of personal touch). I think some of that would come out in discussion but pointing it out as it stood out to me as missing.  Addressing the risks and what risks to be mindful of when exploring AI for something as legally protecting as hiring should be mentioned more.

positive_comments: Like using videos to break up coursework
improvement_opportunities: surprised at oversized clothing selection of speaker. Errors noted in several sections: section 2 - discussion question needs reworded - should say "how do you think AI can consider..." (instead of "think can AI" as it currently states) section 3 - in video, speaker uses terms "ERP" and "PLM" without explaining what these acronyms mean section 6 - related to Role Change Management When Implementing AI, in objectives (under video link) it states ..."foster technologically averse culture."  I believe this is the opposite of the author's intent.

positive_comments: Like video format to break up course work
improvement_opportunities: apparent error in section 3 video objectives - states "AI transforms...but risks stagnation."  Shouldn't it say without AI there are risks of stagnation?
